Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support of Infrared Terahertz Quantum Workshop 2019, To Be Held in Ojai California, September 15-20 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project seeks financial support for enhancing graduate student and postdoc participation, at a Workshop to be held from September 15 to 20, 2019 at Ojai California. The "Infrared Terahertz Quantum Workshop 2019" will focus on a variety of novel physical phenomena in quantum- and electromagnetically-engineered photonic materials in the infrared and terahertz frequency range and the exploitation of these phenomena to create novel optoelectronic devices and applications. The Workshop will host world-renowned experts from leading institutions around the world. It will bring together academic, government, and industry scientists in an intimate venue to encourage close interaction and collaboration. The workshop will foster advances in the leading research of physics of inter-subband related low-dimensional systems, Mid-infrared and THz sources and detectors, collective effects in 2D systems (strong and ultra-strong coupling), Mid-infrared and THz materials and metamaterials and Mid-infrared and THz applications. In addition to about sixty technical talks, the organizers have also planned three plenary talks, ten invited talks. There will also be a poster session with thirty to fifty posters. A "Focused session" will also take place during the workshop. The focused session will be on Polaritonics and Strong Coupling Phenomena. The technical program will provide student participants with the opportunity to gain exposure to physics of inter-subband transitions and related devices and their engineering applications. There will be a vigorous exchange of new ideas on device technology that will benefit to students and young scholars in their pursuit of high-quality research. The meeting will promote scientific exchanges and discussions. The "Infrared Terahertz Quantum Workshop 2019" is expected to play a key role in identifying new directions for research. Exposing the next generation of researchers to these important disciplines is critical for learning how the new Infrared Terahertz Quantum science and technology progresses. Students will gain exposure to the new advances in this field. will allow international interactions and collaboration opportunities among the participants. In addition to the dissemination of scientific information associated with the workshop, the Workshop website will archive the talks, which will be generally available to a wide public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this funding was to support the Infrared Terahertz Quantum Workshop (ITQW 2019), a scientific conference which was held in Ojai, California, from September 15-20, 2019. The topic of the conference was to understand new physics and make new devices that generate, detect, and manipulate light in the infrared and terahertz ranges of the electromagnetic spectrum. This conference specifically addressed approaches that involve the engineering of the quantum mechanical and/or electromagnetic properties of materials. The purpose of the conference was to bring together scientists and engineers to report their latest research, exchange information, start new collaborations. The conference was designed to be relatively small – 126 attendees – a size which is more conducive to intimate scientific discussions and interactions compared to large conferences. The funds requested from NSF specifically went toward participant support costs, in the form of a partial reimbursement for travel and lodging expenses for US student and postdoc participants. Priority was given to students presenting presentations or posters, with a limit of one student funded per PI.

The intellectual merit lies in the scientific and engineering advances reported on and discussed in the conference. Sessions were held on mid-infrared and terahertz quantum-cascade lasers, infrared and terahertz frequency combs, infrared and terahertz photodetectors, plasmonics and metamaterials, and new semiconductor materials. World class researchers gave plenary, tutorial, and invited talks. In particular, one entire day of the workshop was dedicated to a “Focused Session on Polaritonics and Strong Coupling”. This topic explores the fundamental physics of how light interacts with matter, and how these phenomena can be engineered to make new and useful devices. This focused session was designed to attract the top researchers in related fields, and get them together for discussions.

The broader impact of this conference lies in several levels. First, the scientific topics of the conference are highly relevant to future US scientific, industrial, government, and defense applications.  For example, the infrared part of the spectrum is considered to be the “molecular fingerprint” range, i.e. by performing spectroscopy to identify which wavelengths of light are absorbed or not, one can identify what a particular gas is. Another application is the use of mid-infrared lasers as part of an “infrared countermeasures” system which defends aircraft against heat-seeking missiles. The terahertz spectral range is also of interest for applications in astrophysical understating of star formation processes, nondestructive evaluation in industry, and medical imaging. Second, from the point of view of NSF, it was highly beneficial for this conference to be held in the US, which made it much easier for US-based scientists, students, industry engineers, and government officials to attend. Third, the conference has significant industry participation, with many industry submitted talks, industry sponsorship of student prizes, and five companies setting up on-site exhibits. Finally, the direct support of US student travel to the conference encouraged the maximum possible student participation in the conference – a significant benefit to building future domestic workforce.
